title: Understanding monatomic and diatomic gases
text: To calculate the heat transferred to a gas at constant volume, we need to use its molar heat capacity $$C_v$$. Monatomic gases (like helium) have different $$C_v$$ values compared to diatomic gases (like hydrogen and nitrogen).

title: Molar heat capacities $$C_v$$
text: Monatomic gases have a molar $$C_v$$ of $$\frac{3}{2}$$ R, while diatomic gases have a molar $$C_v$$ of $$\frac{5}{2}$$ R. This means diatomic gases can absorb more heat per mole for the same temperature change because they have more degrees of freedom.

title: Heat calculation at constant volume
text: The heat transferred, q, for each gas can be calculated using the formula: $$q=nC_{v\Delta T}$$, where $$n$$ is the number of moles, $$C_v$$ is the molar heat capacity, and ΔT is the change in temperature.

title: Comparing heat transfer for containers
text: Since each container holds the same number of moles and undergoes the same temperature change, the heat transferred is directly proportional to Cv. Subsequently, compare based on whether a gas is monatomic (He, Ne) or diatomic (H₂, N₂).
